docs.snippet: FRANKFURT, Sept. 15 The Frankfurt Book Fair, which opens here tomorrow, will be the biggest in its 28-year postwar history.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Sept. 15 The Frankfurt Book Fair, which opens here tomorrow, will be the biggest in its 28-year postwar history.
docs.abstract: Comment on Frankfurt Book Fair scheduled to open Sept 16; theme of fair is Latin Amer--An Unknown Literary Continent; Latin Amer writers who will attend noted; Internatl PEN pres Mario Vargas Llosa and fair dir Peter Weidhaas comment; fair includes displays from 68 countries, with 278,000 titles, of which 83,000 are new; Farrar Straus Giroux pres Roger Straus Jr comments; Vargas Llosa por (M)

byline.original: By HERBERT MITGANG Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay Uruguay has broken out of a stifling economic protectionism, learned how to export, and is cashing in on world demand for labor-intensive products.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay Uruguay has broken out of a stifling economic protectionism, learned how to export, and is cashing in on world demand for labor-intensive products.
docs.abstract: Uruguay dispenses with system of stifling econ protectionism in favor of increasing foreign trade; exports for 1st 7 mos of '76 have soared to $312-million; nation's new aggressive sales campaigns abroad discussed; illus (M)

headline.main: Uruguay Relaxes Its Economic Protection As Military Leaders Promote Exporting

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: PARIS, Sept. 26 "The increasing use of kidnapping, torture and political murder" in Argentina, Chile and Uruguay and "recent mass arrests of trade unionists" In Turkey are Amnesty International's chief concerns, according to a statement issued today.
docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 26 "The increasing use of kidnapping, torture and political murder" in Argentina, Chile and Uruguay and "recent mass arrests of trade unionists" In Turkey are Amnesty International's chief concerns, according to a statement issued today.
docs.abstract: Amnesty Internatl ends conf, Strasbourg, France, on human rights violations in 112 countries; says its chief concerns are 'increasing use of kidnapping, torture and pol murder' in Argentina, Chile and Uruguay and 'recent mass arrest of trade unionists' in Turkey (S)

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 29 Uruguay's military leaders have reacted with indignation to the recent ban by the United States Congress on further military aid to their Government, which is accused of systematic violations of human rights.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 29 Uruguay's military leaders have reacted with indignation to the recent ban by the United States Congress on further military aid to their Government, which is accused of systematic violations of human rights.
docs.abstract: Uruguay's mil leaders are angry over recent US Cong ban on further mil aid to their Govt because of purported violations of human rights and treatment of prisoners by officials there, stemming from its fight on revolutionary subversion; Aparicio Mendez Govt is militantly anti-Communist and looks for support to Chile, Paraguay and other mil regimes in region; ban, approved as amendment to '77 Foreign Assistance Act and introduced by Repr Edward I Koch, ends program involving about $3-million in arms credits and financing of training for Uruguyan officers and enlisted men at US mil installations (M)

headline.main: Uruguay's Military Leaders Angry Over Congressional Cutoff on Aid for Arms

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: BOSTON, Oct. 20 In dealing with the world, Henry Kissinger said the other day, "we must distinguish morality from moralizing." Even those who do not regard the Secretary of State as a pre-eminent moral philosopher will accept the importance of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Oct. 20 In dealing with the world, Henry Kissinger said the other day, "we must distinguish morality from moralizing." Even those who do not regard the Secretary of State as a pre-eminent moral philosopher will accept the importance of the distinction.
docs.abstract: A Lewis article on question of morality in US foreign policy as conducted by Sec Kissinger; scores US aid to repressive regimes in Brazil, Chile and other Latin-Amer nations and urges combining morality with practical policy by at least stating opposition to practices alien to Amer ideals
